body: Patrice Carter and Doreen Simpson tasted the love, though briefly. Their in-boxes overflowed with e-mail in early October, just days after City Room visited A Taste of Hawthorne, the West Indian-inspired restaurant run by both women out of Ms. Carter's backyard in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens in Brooklyn on Saturdays and Sundays. Neighbors who had
title: CITY ROOM; A Tiny Restaurant Agrees To Cease and Desist, but ...

body: 'HALLOWHOA!' When you watch a tour guide in ''Hallowhoa!'' strap on a backpack with a long hose and a pump attached, you can't help thinking of Dan Aykroyd and Bill Murray suiting up in ''Ghostbusters.'' But the equipment here is not designed to vacuum stray ghouls and blobs of ectoplasm; it's to spray them silly. ''Silly spray'' plays a key role
title: SPARE TIMES, For Children

body: Laura Shirk-Charles stopped by her next-door neighbor's home for dinner the other night in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens in Brooklyn. She ordered salmon sliders right off the menu. To go. While she waited, Ms. Shirk-Charles chatted up a table of 20-somethings in the backyard who were already eating. Her 13-month-old son, Henry, played with Ori, a
title: CITY ROOM; Home Cooking, For Eating Out

body: The ''Living In'' article last Sunday about Prospect-Lefferts Gardens, Brooklyn, misstated the name of a street in the neighborhood's historic district. As an accompanying map showed, it is Rutland Road, not Rutland Street.
title: CORRECTIONS

body: KIMBERLEE AULETTA grew up in Midtown, and for a long time Manhattan was where she imagined she would stay. Despite family roots in Brooklyn, where her father had grown up, she had never really considered moving there. But time brought a few epiphanies. The first came in a late 1990s winter, when friends who had moved to Brooklyn invited her to a
title: LIVING IN; History All Around, and Greenery Next Door

author: E-mail: realprop@nytimes.com
body: $9.75 MILLION 115 Ocean Avenue (between Lincoln Road and Parkside Avenue) Prospect-Lefferts Gardens, Brooklyn A local investor has bought this six-story 1920s apartment building with 86 units for nine-and-a-half times the rent roll. Buyer: Lincoln Prospect Associates L.L.C. Seller: 115 Ocean L.L.C. Brokers: Aaron Jungreis, Rosewood Realty Group
title: TRANSACTIONS; Recent Sale

body: AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites HISTORIC RICHMOND TOWN Saturday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m., the second annual Uncorked! food festival, featuring demonstrations by Staten Island culinary professionals. There will also be a cheese school and lessons on pairing cheese with the right wine. 441 Clarke Avenue, Staten Island, (718) 351-1611, Ext. 236,
title: Spare Times

body: NEW YORK CITY Manhattan, May 1 Around 10 residences will be open from 10:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. for the 15th annual benefit house tour of the Junior League of New York. The homes will include the five-story town house of Julie Marshall, a designer. It is decorated with modern and 20th-century furniture and several unusual chandeliers. Also on display
title: An Open Invitation To Visit

body: A 2-year-old Brooklyn boy was left on a school bus for two hours on Tuesday after the driver and the bus matron forgot to drop him off at day care, then went to their homes for a break, the police said. Officers found the child in the bus, parked outside the driver's Brighton Beach home, about 10:30 a.m. after a passer-by heard the boy crying and
title: Boy, 2, Left on School Bus for Two Hours

body: FOR Judith HoSang, a travel industry publicist, redecorating the bedroom she shares with her husband, Robert HoSang, a media buyer for a marketing company, had been an exercise in frustration. ''We really, really need some help,'' pleaded Ms. HoSang, 29, in a short video she sent by e-mail to The New York Times in response to a message on its Web
title: ON THE CHEAP; A Pesky Bedroom, Tamed by Pattern

author: E-mail: citycritic@nytimes.com
body: As soon as they heard about the earthquake, Haitians in Brooklyn started making their way to Savoir Faire, the record store in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens, to pool what little information anyone had. And they also brought supplies to send back home -- clothing, canned fruit, ramen, cases of bottled water. By early last week, the donations had been
title: CITY CRITIC; Three Steps to Making Smart Haiti Donations
